All the reflections catch in the glass buildings of Manha The traffic in the streets, the old turn-of-the-century f the people walking on the sidewalk, the pigeons flying aw Brooklyn Bridge and the Manhattan skyline reflecting off surface of the Hudson River...
Seen through the mirrored surfaces, everything in the cit to move in a distorted way. Ominous. The softness of the sun's rising light is contrasted with eerie, haunting music.

Bip. Bip. Bip... It's 8 a.m. The blinking digital numbers of the alarm clo reflect off the wooden floor of the apartment. The sunlight is diffused through the drawn curtains of th living room. Seen in the reflection of the TV-set, a man is sleeping o couch. He switches off the alarm and rises to go into the bathroom.

Like a thick fog, the steam from the shower fills the bat The shower turns off. A hand reaches out to wipe away the on the mirror above the sink, revealing- The face of BEN CARSON, 41 years old. His eyes reflect th hardships of life. A life, that from the lines on his fac suspect hasn't been easy. On his chest and shoulder, SEVE BULLET SCARS. Ben changes his razor blade and starts to shave his 3 day stubble.
Ben finishes getting dressed and walks to the half opened bedroom door. Inside, ANGELA is asleep in the bed. She is younger than ANGELA awakens slowly-
What time is it?
Almost 8:30... Coffee?
No, you're going to be late.
Go back to sleep... I'll call you, OK?
Yeah, I won't be working until later                     tonight.
He comes to kiss her on the forehead. She opens a sleepy smiles.
You shaved?
She strokes his face gently.
I like it. It makes you look younger.
Ben slips on his old military parka before leaving.
Good luck!
See you later, Angie.
Ben walks down the hallway. The building is old and clear well maintained, cracks and graffiti cover the walls.
The downtown streets are clogged with the early morning r hour traffic.
On the honorary board of the NYPD we can read the names o the officers decorated for their courage. In the reflecti the copper plate we find Ben, sitting on the bench across the office of -
Captain LARRY BYRNE (55) who appears at the end of the co
Sorry, I'm late... Have you been                       waiting long?
I just got here.                                       They shake hands.
You look awful.
Thanks Larry.
You know, you should sleep at night.                   Come in...                                             Ben follows him into the office.
Larry takes a seat and briefly looks over the messages an that have been dropped off on his desk-
So did you find an apartment yet?
No, not yet.
You need a place to stay?
No, I'm staying at my sister's, in                     Queens.
I didn't know you had a sister. What                   does she do?
She's a bartender.

That's not too good for you! Anyway,                   you know you are always welcome to                     stay at our house.                                     Larry looks up at Ben, slightly uneasy-
I ran into Amy the other day. How are                   things going between the two of you?                    Ben remains silent. He obviously doesn't want to get into subject.
So, why did you want to see me Ben?
You know what I want. I'm ready to                      come back, I'm feeling much better                      now.

Listen Ben, I can't bring you back on                   the force. Nobody in the squad wants                    you around right now. I'm sorry but I                   have to be honest with you. You                         understand, right?
Larry, I'm telling you, I'm ready.

If it was up to me, I would bring you                   back tomorrow, but I'm not the only                     one who decides. Listen, I think I've                   got something else for you. I know a                    guy at the Mayflower corporation and                    they need someone to watch over one of                  their department stores.
What?! Come on Larry, a security guard                  job... I'm not ready to retire yet!

Hey! I'm just trying to help here. I                    know you're over qualified for that                     position but it's a good opportunity                    for you for the time being...until the                  situation here quiets down. Also the                    money is not that bad.                                  Ben is having a hard time to contain his anger.

You need the money, Ben. You're in the                  middle of a divorce and you've got                      child support to cover. If you want to                  see your kids, you've got to get a                      job, any job.                                           Deep inside, Ben knows Larry's right.
Do you know the Mayflower on West 38th                    Street?
I do. The one that burned down?

Yes, their night watchman hasn't shown                    up for work in several days. They need                    someone right away. Take it, relax,                       and we will talk about your situation                     again in a couple months.
Yeah, in a couple months... I gave                        everything for the NYPD. I almost died                    out there. Everyone seems to have                         forgotten that.
I didn't.

We discover a whole different world- In the sterile environment of the NYC Chief Medical Exami Office, forensic scientists with tape recorders in hand, describe the corpses. We are a world away from the Hollywood cliches of neatly out, immaculate cadavers. Here, some of the corpses have a state of advanced decomposition and others are still fr contorted positions, expressing their ultimate agony befo dying. From the homeless man fished out of the river, to woman killed by gun shots, each corpse tells his own stor Amidst the group of doctors 35-year-old AMY, deeply immer an autopsy, is interrupted by her cell phone. Amy checks the display for the incoming call- BEN. She he for a moment and doesn't answer the call. Amy goes back to the postmortem analysis on her tape reco
Dozens of pigeons fly away as the above ground subway pas
" ...You have reached Amy Carson. I am                  not available to take your call. Please leave a message and I will get back to you as soon as I can."
Caught in the pouring rain, Ben has taken shelter under t scaffolding at a street corner. He plugs his ear with his to block the traffic and city commotion -

(on Amy's voicemail) Amy, it's me... I just wanted to let you know that I got a job today... It's                     nothing special, just a security guard                  job... If you still want to go ahead                    with it, we can sign the divorce papers... I mean, if that's what you really want.                                            (he hesitates) I've been thinking about Michael's                      birthday tomorrow. It would be nice if                  we could celebrate it together ... You know, for the kids' sake... Call me...                  Please.
Ben hangs up the phone. He lingers under the scaffolding moment, watching the falling rain.
The glass skyscrapers mirror the black clouds in the sky as they slowly break up, giving way to the sun.

On 38th Street, just off of Broadway, the Mayflower has withstood the passage of time and the huge fire that forc to shut down- The damage from the fire is still noticeable on the facad the building- The fire appears to have started on the ground floor and to have spread all the way up to the top. Some of the win are shattered, while others are boarded up. What was once impressive ornate building, a fine example of 1920's architecture standing on one of Manhattan's most dynamic streets, now gives off a feeling of devastation and desol What is left of it is a mere ruin, a sort of neglected gh ship, abandoned in the heart of the city.

The last beams of daylight shine through the broken windo Inside the department store, everything has remained the since the fire, as if time stood still. The display cases departments, the mannequins, and even the clothes are all or blackened by the fire. A thick coat of soot covers the and rainwater drips down all over the place.

It's been five years and they're still                   in a legal battle with the insurance                     companies. Even cleaning up that mess                    is impossible...                                         In his dark brown uniform, the daytime security guard, LO SAPELLI, 60's, seems pleased to guide Ben through what wa a temple of beauty and vanity.

You know, the Meredith family acquired                   this building after St. John's                           Hospital closed in 1952. It was the                      very first Mayflower to open on the                      East Coast.                                              On the cracked walls, THE HUGE 1920 MIRRORS that have sur the flames reflect merely the remnants of the past. The customers are long gone and have been replaced by pigeons in and out of the gaps in the roof.

The company wants us to patrol the                       premises every couple of hours, but I do my rounds every three hours and that's more than enough. Anyway, you'll see, there's not much going on. It's pretty calm around here. Ben follows Lorenzo through the burnt display counters. H listens but his mind has drifted elsewhere. This place ma uncomfortable. It's not only the lingering smell of a fir also a sense of death that hangs over it. The whistling of the wind through the store's old ventila system sounds like faraway voices. Ben and Lorenzo appear at the top of the staircase of the floor.
Here you go... Men's department, or what's left of it anyway...
Ben observes the surroundings- Yet another spectacle of devastation.

Thank God you didn't show up any later. This place gives me the chills at night. ... No electricity, and all these mirrors... You know, I live in                     Brooklyn near a Jewish neighborhood,                     and when someone dies, they cover all                    the mirrors in their house. Some say that it's just to renounce all vanity during the mourning period, but others say something else... They say it's to keep the soul of the dead from being trapped in the mirrors... Believe it                     or not, there's always a bit of truth in any superstition. Am I right?
Amused and skeptical at the same time, Ben contemplates t mirrors that surround him-
I guess you just have to keep your eyes away from them.
Unlike the rest of the scenery, THE MIRRORS ARE PERFECTLY AND GLISTENING.
Did you clean them?
What?
The mirrors, why are they so clean?
Lorenzo smiles-
That's Gary Lewis, the fellow who                        worked here before you. He was completely obsessed with these damn mirrors. He'd spend the entire night polishing them.
Why did he leave?
No idea. Just didn't show up one night. I take it he's found a better                     opportunity somewhere else.

I'm not one to complain, but I never really liked him much... Could never be bothered to say hello or at least ask "how are you doing?"... I mean, damn, do we work together as a team or what?! You, on the other hand, seem like a nice guy. How long has it been since                      you left the NYPD?
Almost a year.
Why did you resign from the force? You                    were a detective, is that correct?
I was wounded during a holdup... It kind                  of changed my perspective on things.                      Ben and Lorenzo reach the next floor.

Third floor... Ladies' department. You gotta be careful here. When the wind blows, sometimes the tiles fly off the roof and they'll just snap your ear off, if you follow what I'm saying... Lorenzo checks the time on his watch.
Well, I'll let you get acquainted with the rest of the store on your own. They turn around.
Follow me, I'll show you our "headquarters" and I'll get you one of these uniforms.
It's almost night. Ben and Lorenzo have finished their vi exit the department store.

We were a pretty big team working here                    before the fire. When you stop to                         think that of all the department                          stores in New York, this one was the                      most beautiful, the most luxurious... It                  breaks your heart, it really does...
Outside the building behind the fence blocking its entry, construction trailer has been outfitted for the guards.
Here you go. This is where you'll be spending most of your time. At least you've got electricity in here. It's nice and warm, and there's even a TV.
Cartoons flicker on an old television set. All bundled up coat, and wearing a woolen hat, a young boy is watching T Lorenzo and Ben enter the mobile home-
Lorenzo Junior, my grandson... Say hello Lorenzo.
Hello.
Lorenzo and I are going to the movies tonight...
Lorenzo strokes his grandson on the head and proceeds to back of the mobile home, leaving Ben alone with the child boy looks almost hypnotized by the images on TV.
How old are you, Lorenzo?
Lorenzo Jr. shifts his attention from the cartoons and st Ben in the face-
Do you work in the department store?
I do now.
Grandpa says there are ghosts in the store... Is that true?
Ben smiles.
I think your grandpa just wants to scare you a little.
Lorenzo Senior has changed clothes, and returns with a un which he hands over to Ben-
Here, this should fit you. Lorenzo, put your coat on... We are already late. (to Ben, on the sly) There's a drop of Jack Daniel's in the cupboard... To keep yourself warm.
Lorenzo hands over the keys-
Well, Ben, the place is all yours.
He's about to leave when-

Oh! I forgot the most important thing... the flashlights! You'll be needing one of these at night. We've got two of them. They run on batteries. Don't forget to charge them... See you in the morning, Ben.
See you tomorrow.

Lorenzo and Lorenzo Jr. exit the trailer. Through the win Ben sees them walk out to the street. Ben inspects the trailer- scattered with knickknacks, the decoration of the place corresponds well with Lorenzo's personality - warmhearted and humble. The clock on the wall shows 7 p.m.... A long night lies a Ben grabs a flashlight and turns it on. The beam of light dazzling-

The flashlight sweeps across the dark entrance hall. Wearing the security guard's uniform marked with an embro "M", Ben makes his first round of the store. The pigeons perched on the roof seem to observe him. Ben proceeds slowly up the stairs.
In the Men's department, Ben's flashlight is a mere lumin spot twirling in the night. The ever-present mirrors magnify the space to infinity.

Ben walks through the different sections of the Ladies' department. He examines the remains of the charred garmen sagging on the hangers. The silhouettes of the burnt mannequins emerge in the glo the night. STRANGE AND DISTURBING SHAPES REFLECT OFF THE MIRRORS.
Wide exterior shot- By night, the department store's ornate facade takes on a entirely different appearance - more menacing, almost evi

Ben continues his rounds. We follow his path through reflections in the mirrors- AS IF HE WAS BEING WATCHED... Then- For the first time, we discover another perspective, anot FROM WITHIN THE MIRRORS. It feels ominous, slightly detac The sound is muted. Ben crosses back the third floor- The second floor...

In the reflection of one of the grand mirrors in the entr hall, we see Ben come down the stairs. He stops for a mom facing his reflection in the mirror. He fixes his collar and looks at himself in his new cloth quite an NYPD uniform... Suddenly, his eyes freeze. Intrigued, he comes closer to mirror and leans forward- A HANDPRINT, BARELY VISIBLE, ON THE ICE COLD SURFACE. He touches it with the tip of his fingers and tries to ru off, unsuccessfully. He picks up a rag from the ground, s the mirror, and rubs the mark fervently. The print remain confirms his hunch- THE HANDPRINT IS INSIDE THE MIRROR... text: It's been snowing all day and a white coat of powder outl the trees and houses. On the front lawn of their house, 5 year old MICHAEL and old DAISY are building a snowman.
Why did they say on TV that it wasn't supposed to snow today, but tomorrow instead? Why did they lie?
Sometimes they make mistakes, Michael. It happens...
Grown-ups don't make mistakes. Only little children do.
Slightly annoyed, the little boy places the eyes on the s Daisy's face lights up with a big smile when she catches of her father's car approaching-
Daddy!
Michael turns around and sees Ben exiting his 1986 Oldsmo with a big wrapped package in his arms. The children abandon their snowman and rush towards their father. Ben takes Michael into his arms-
(pointing to the wrapped present) What is that?
Well I don't know, I just found this package hidden behind a tree.
Is it for me?
Maybe... (to his daughter) Daisy, has Michael been a good boy? Does he deserve his birthday present?
Michael nods.
No! Yesterday he finished the whole bag of candy when mom had told him he could only have one piece.
Not true!
Yes it's true!
No, it's not true... She's lying Daddy. I've been a very good boy, I promise.
They enter the house.
Is mom back?
Not yet. Rosa came to pick us up from school today.
In the kitchen, ROSA, the nanny, is rinsing the dishes fr afternoon snack-
Hello Rosa!
Hello Senor Carson. How are you?
I'm good, very good... What time will Amy be back?
Not before six, Sir...
OK, I'll wait for her.
Do you want me to fix you a snack?
No, thank you. I'll be fine.
Ben takes off his coat and joins the kids in the living r hands over the present to his son. Daisy is sitting in the armchair, holding her cat, TIGER, arms.
Happy birthday, Michael.
What is it?
Duh, open it stupid!
Michael tears away the wrapping paper and discovers a rem control car. The little boy is on cloud nine.
Through the front window, we see a Volvo station wagon pa front of the house. Amy gets out of the car, loaded with shopping bags. She enters the house and hands the groceri to Rosa.
Hi Rosa... Where are the kids?
Upstairs...                                             (in a low voice) ...With Senor Ben.

The expression on Amy's face shifts. Noticeably irritated goes up to the second floor. Michael's remote control car drives at full speed down th hallway. Ben shows his children how to operate the remote control while the bathtub fills up. He seems as excited a kids by the new toy. Ben turns around to find Amy watching them.
Hey Amy...
Look Mommy, look what Daddy got me.
It's great, you will have to show me                    how it works!
It's so fast Mommy!
Ben, can I talk to you, in private?
Ben puts down the remote control-
(to his kids) Ok kids, it's time for your bath. No                    fooling around.
Ben follows Amy into the bedroom. She closes the door beh them.
Amy is not equally pleased to see him- She's beside herse anger-
What is this? I already asked you not to drop by without calling, didn't I?
I do, but you never take my calls!
I don't need your calls in the middle                   of the night. I'm better off without them.
I haven't had a drink in three months                   but, then again, how would you know?
I don't want to know, Ben. I don't want to hear about it. It's not my problem. You're not my problem. You've                  done more than enough harm already.
You don't think people can change?
We are not talking about people, we're talking about you. How many times did you tell me you were gonna change and nothing happened? It only got worse.
Ben moves closer to his ex-wife-
Just give me another chance.
She smiles- How many other chances did she already give h Behind the firmness and intransigence she conveys, we sen is torn. She still loves him as well.
I need more time, Ben. Listen, I will                     never stop you from seeing your                           children but we have to set up some                       rules.
Out of nowhere, Ben hits the wall with his bare fist-
WHAT RULES?! IT'S MY SON'S FUCKING                        BIRTHDAY TODAY! COME ON AMY, WHAT RULE                    IS GOING TO STOP ME FROM SEEING HIM?
In the bathtub, Daisy and Michael cannot avoid overhearin parents arguing. In denial, Michael blocks his ears with hands and lies back under the water...
Amy seems distrustful of Ben, scared of how close he is t edge. We can see the anger in his eyes...
Look at yourself. You're still                            carrying around so much of that anger.
He catches a glimpse of his reflection in the mirror- and desperate violence in his eyes... Ben steps back.
(trying to calm down)                                 I'm sorry, I didn't mean to yell at                       you... Things could be so different                       between us.
Yes I know, but it's up to you Ben.
Yeah... Anyway, I wasn't planning on                    staying. My shift starts in an hour.                    I'll just kiss them goodbye and then                    I'm leaving.

Ben exits the room. Amy is left alone- Through the window, she watches Ben exit the house and ge his car. When she turns away, she discovers Michael and Daisy stan outside the bathtub dripping wet in their towels. She smi and quickly comes to dry them.
Mom?
Yes, honey.
Is Daddy coming back to live with us?
She smiles gently.
I don't know sweetheart. I don't know.

The beams from the flashlight are reflected in the few in water flooding the basement corridor. Since yesterday, th level has continued to rise. The outline of Ben and Lorenzo's silhouettes appear in th staircase leading to the ground floor-
I haven't managed to find the source of the leak. My guess is it doesn't come from the store... It must be a municipal pipe that blew with the cold...
I'll call the company tomorrow morning                  and have them come take a look at it.

A busy street under the subway overpass. We see a neighbo bar on the corner-
At this time of day the place is deserted. A plasma scree a baseball game. A drunk guy is half asleep at the corner

Sitting at the bar, Ben is nervous, tense... He removes t steeped tea bag from his cup. Ben stares at himself in the mirror, behind the bottle di shelves. It is not his mirror image that he is observing. gaze seems to pierce through his own reflection, to dive into the very depths of his soul. Angela interrupts, across from him, behind the bar. She w here.
(intrigued) What are you looking at?
Nothing special...
(playfully) Come on, you've been looking at                         yourself for more than half an hour.                    You never used to be so vain.

What are you talking about?

The mirrors... In the department                        store, at every street corner, in the                   windows of every fucking building in                    this city. Angela smiles, not sure if he is serious-
You need a drink.

Ben observes the palm of his hand.

In the darkness, a rat glides peacefully on the water sur In the basement, the water level continues to rise. With a flashlight in hand, and his feet submerged in the Ben moves deeper into the tunnel. He is searching for the source of the leak. The beam of l sweeps across the walls and the piping.
